clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Catheter on Postoperative Urinary Retention
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Indwelling Foley Placement, Immediate Post-Operative Straight Catheterization, or No Catheterization on Post-operative Urinary Retention After Transforaminal Lumbar Interbody Fusions

brief_summary.textblock: To determine if indwelling Foley placement at the onset of the procedure, straight catherization at the conclusion of the procedure, or no catheterization produces the lowest rates of postoperative urinary retention after transforaminal lumbar interbody fusions (TLIFs).

detailed_description.textblock:
Post-operative urinary retention (POUR) is one the most common post-operative complications after elective spine surgeries. Common causes of postoperative urinary retention (POUR) include bladder stenosis, distension, trauma due to catheterizations, age, and prostate hyperplasia. The incidence of POUR increases with age, gender, types of surgery conducted, any comorbidities such as cerebral palsy or multiple sclerosis, use of drugs such as anticholinergic agents, beta blockers, or sympathomimetics, and use of IV fluids.
This condition has been associated with the development of UTIs and sepsis, increased post-operative length of stay (LOS), and 90-day readmission after surgery. In the field of spine surgery, the reported incidence of POUR is highly variable, and there is no consensus on effective methods of prevention. We set out to assess POUR from patients catheterized compared to non-catheterized following a transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion.

clinical_study.why_stopped: PI initiated closure due to limited clinical resources and lack of participation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: If patient has the ability to spontaneously urinate

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: Post-void bladder volume obtained from ultrasound bladder scan

primary_outcome.measure: Need for straight catheterization or post-operative indwelling Foley catheter placement
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: Did patient need straight catheterization due to urinary retention

primary_outcome.measure: Initiation of an alpha-1 inhibitor post-operatively
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: Did patient receive an alpha-1 inhibitor post-operatively?

primary_outcome.measure: Urologic consultations for evaluation of post-operative urinary complications
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: Did patient have a urology consultation?
Did the patient acquire a urinary tract infection?
Did the patient acquire a urinary tract infection?
Did the patient acquire a urinary tract infection?

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery until the date of hospital discharge, up to 1 month postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: How long was the patients post-operative stay?

arm_group.description: straight catheterization (in-and-out straight catheterization) will take place at the end of the surgery

intervention.description: The patient is catheterized during surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing a primary single-level MIS TLIF (Diagnosis: radiculopathy, stenosis, herniated nucleus pulposus, degenerative disc disease, spondylosis, osteophytic complexes, spondylolysis, spondylolisthesis)
- Patients able to provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with baseline urinary dysfunction requiring manual bladder emptying via intermittent straight catheterization, suprapubic catheters, or other indwelling catheters. -Allergies or other contraindications to medicines in the post- operative urinary retention protocol
- Lack of consent

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
